events.name: Android Wear Hackday
events.description:
Join us in FA-358 (Fraser building) for a full day of Android Wear development, broken down as follows:

10:00 - Introduction to Android Wear
11:00 - Android Wear design sprint
12:30 - Food break
13:00 - Optional: Android Wear hands-on tutorial by Mike Daoust!
14:00 - Hackathon
18:00 - Wrap-up / hand out prizes**

** We're hoping to be able to get sponsors to donate some prizes, such as Android Wear watches and/or tablets and/or phones, but we're still at the early stages, so we can't guarantee anything at this point.﻿

Google+ Event

events.name: Polymer hackday
events.description:
A full day of hacking the web with Polymer--a library built on Web Components that enables developers to create their own encapsulated, custom HTML elements!

Much of the day will consist of self-guided tutorials, but of course we will collaborate to learn together :)

Rough agenda

10:00 AM: Arrival: coffee + muffins + warm greetings

10:15 AM: Introductory presentation

11:00 AM: Polymer basics (interactive samples)

11:15 AM: Tutorial codelab

12:00 PM: Lunch

12:30 PM: Maps codelab

1:00 PM: Self-guided codelabs -- or hack on your own project

4:30 PM: Show off your work, compare notes and thoughts, wrap up

Prerequisites: Participants will be expected to be comfortable with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Having access to a computer on which they can edit HTML, CSS, and JavaScript will be extremely helpful!

Location: FA-358, in the Fraser Science Building

Parking: Is apparently available in visitors' parking lots for free, as Security does not check for the pay-and-display tickets on weekends.

events.name: Android Study Jam
events.description:
Join us to work through the Udacity "Developing Android Apps: Android Fundamentals" course. The course materials are all free; you only have to pay if you want to receive an official certificate from Udacity at the end of the course. 

Each week we're going to meet to discuss the work we accomplished and the difficulties we encountered on the previous section of the course. So on February 4th, we expect you to have completed Lesson 1; on February 11th, Lesson 2, etc.

events.name: Android Study Jam

venue.name: LU Math and Computer Science Club Room, Laurentian University
venue.address_1: 935 Ramsey Lake Road, Sudbury, ON P3E 2C6

events.description:
Note: Dan is sick, so we're changing the location of the meetup to the LU Math and Computer Science Club Room.

This week, we're going to discuss our experiences working through Lesson 2 and help each other through any hurdles we encountered. Come prepared!

Join us to work through the Udacity "Developing Android Apps: Android Fundamentals" course. The course materials are all free; you only have to pay if you want to receive an official certificate from Udacity at the end of the course. 

Each week we're going to meet to discuss the work we accomplished and the difficulties we encountered on the previous section of the course.
events.how_to_find_us: Just around the corner from the usual FA-358 room.

events.name: Android Study Jam
events.description:
This week we'll expect you to have completed Lesson 3 of the Udacity "Developing Android Apps: Android Fundamentals" course. The course materials are all free; you only have to pay if you want to receive an official certificate from Udacity at the end of the course. 

Each week we're going to meet to discuss the work we accomplished and the difficulties we encountered on the previous section of the course.

Each week we're going to meet to discuss the work we accomplished and the difficulties we encountered on the previous section of the course.

events.description:

The course materials are all free; you only have to pay if you want to receive an official certificate from Udacity at the end of the course.

events.name: Android Study Jam
events.description:
This week we'll expect you to have completed Lesson 6 of the Udacity "Developing Android Apps: Android Fundamentals" course.

The course materials are all free; you only have to pay if you want to receive an official certificate from Udacity at the end of the course. 

Each week we're going to meet to discuss the work we accomplished and the difficulties we encountered on the previous section of the course.

events.name: Android study jam - grand finale!
events.description:
We started the Android Study Jam back in February, worked through eight weeks of self-study to complete the course, then took a break for university exams... but now those who have made it through the course must gather to show off our final projects.

The fruits of our learnings and labours shall be unveiled--and the grand champion shall receive a corresponding prize!

Also, it will be a good opportunity to discuss the rapidly approaching Google I/O. :)

events.name: Google I/O Extended
events.description:
Join other GDG Sudbury members to watch the first day of Google I/O streamed live!

The keynote kicks off at 12:00 PM, and you won't want to miss it; after that, there will be a selection of other live streamed sessions. Sure, you could watch it at home by yourself, but it's way more fun with other people.

Also, there will be a giveaway of various items... but only for those who attend!

events.name: Firebase Introduction and Codelab
events.description:
Join us for an evening of exploring Firebase through an introductory presentation followed by a codelab! Please bring a laptop to follow along during the codelab (everyone should, it's more fun!) .

Just a few things to set-up before hand to get started right away:

- Sign-up for Firebase: http://www.firebase.com 

- Be familiar with HTML/JS/CSS

Firebase is a powerful platform for your mobile and web application.  Firebase can power your app’s backend, including data storage, user authentication, static hosting, and more. With Firebase, you can easily build mobile and web apps that scale from one user to one million.
events.how_to_find_us: The TimeHero Office is located on the second floor of the building in Suite 201. Parking is available at the Beech St. lot or Energy Court for free. Consult http://www.greatersudbury.ca/living/parking/downtown-sudbury/#free for more information.

events.name: GDG Sudbury DevFest
events.description:
Join us for a full day of talks and hands-on sessions covering a variety of technologies, including the following confirmed sessions:

• 9:30 - 11:00 Intro to Python (Kacey Cayen of HapSys)

• 11:00 - 12:00 AngularJS (Sarah Paajanen & Emily Bamsey of TimeHero.co)

• 1:00 - 2:00 Google Cast (David Pellegrini)

• 2:00 - 3:30 Polymer / Material Design (Steven Zarichney, ClaimSecure)

• 3:30 - 4:00 Lightning talks (you!)

• 4:00 - 5:00 Google Compute Engine (Dan Scott, Laurentian University)

And still to-be-confirmed:

• Wearables

Lightning talks - If you're interested in giving a talk and leading a hands-on session on one of these topics, or another topic related to development with Google technologies, let us know! A few five or ten minute talks would help keep the energy level of the day nice and high.

Come out and join us! Admission is free and all are welcome.

And check out the cool room we have booked at NOSM (with lots of wifi and power).

events.name: Android game development: a chat with Aaron Langille
events.description:
Aaron Langille is a well-known computer science professor at Laurentian University, particularly for the game design specialization--and he not only talks the talk, he walks the walk: this fall, as part of Cerebellum Bug Games (a small independent game development company), he brought Vladimir to the Google Play Store.

Aaron is joining us to generously share his experiences with cross-platform game development (Vladimir runs on both iOS and Android); the independent game dev industry; the Game Maker platform for development; promotion and marketing; and what's next for Vladimir.
events.how_to_find_us: Room 30-254, in the back right-hand corner of the Library

events.name: Android for Beginners study group
events.description:
Join us to work through the Android for Beginners course (videos, tests, and practical assignments) as we learn to build Android apps from the ground up. You don't even have to know how to program to start with this course!

Please bring a laptop. We'll walk through getting Android Studio installed and dive into a few high-level concepts before compiling and deploying your first application on your Android phone or tablet (or, failing that, onto an Android emulator you can run on your laptop.)

Admission is free, and light food & drink will be provided.
events.how_to_find_us: Head up to the fourth floor of the Fraser Auditorium building to find the F-441 lab.

events.name: Android Development for Beginners study group
events.description:
For week two of the Android Development for Beginners course, please bring a laptop! And note the new location: the Brenda Wallace Computer Lab in the J.N. Desmarais Library at Laurentian University. (More power!)

After finishing Lesson 1B as homework, our focus will be to work through Practical Exercise #1 together. This exercise walks you through getting Android Studio installed and running before compiling and deploying your first application on your Android phone or tablet (or, failing that, onto an Android emulator you can run on your laptop.)

By the end of the exercise, you'll have created a personalized greeting card app for the special person/people in your life!

Admission is free, and light food & drink will be provided for those who RSVP.﻿
events.how_to_find_us: Brenda Wallace Computer Lab - on your left as you enter the library

events.name: Android Development for Beginners study group
events.description:
Our Android Development for Beginners study jam continues!

This week we'll work through lesson 2B before our break at 7:00, and jump into practice set #2 after the break. So please ensure that you've completed practice set #1 and lesson 2A before you arrive.

Admission is free, and light food & drink will be provided for those who RSVP.﻿
events.how_to_find_us: Brenda Wallace Computer Lab - on your left as you enter the library

events.name: Android for Beginners study group, week 4
events.description:
This week, please finish practice set #2 (variables! variable scope! reading code! building a basketball counter app) and try to work through Lesson 3A (introduction to object oriented programming), so that we can focus on Lesson 3B and preparing for your final project: creating a "teach 5 new things to people" app that's all yours, from design to code.

Admission is free, and light food & drink (water fountains count, right?) will be provided.
events.how_to_find_us: Brenda Wallace Computer Lab - on your left as you enter the library

events.name: Android for Beginners study group: final projects!
events.description:
This week, please finish Lesson 3B (object oriented programming in Android) and launch into your final project: creating a "teach 5 new things to people" app that's all yours, from design to code, using the skills you've learned along the way. Please consult the Final Project Rubric to ensure that you meet or exceed expectations, for the purposes of the final certificate.

We'll compare what everyone has accomplished, and help each other cross the finish line with design and implementation assistance. It's going to rock!

Admission is free, and light food & drink (water fountains count, right?) will be provided.
events.how_to_find_us: Brenda Wallace Computer Lab - on your left as you enter the library

events.name: Unity Game Engine demo
events.description:
Join us in room C112, in the recently renovated classroom building, for an introduction to the Unity Game Engine. This is a great opportunity to learn the fundamentals about Unity!

In subsequent sessions, we'll build on your Android development skills to combine the two technologies to build a virtual reality app for Google Cardboard (https://developers.google.com/cardboard/unity/).

This event is brought to you in partnership with the Laurentian University Game Design program.﻿

events.name: Women in Technology
events.description:
Join us to discuss women in technology! There will be a talk from TimeHero's CTO, Sarah Paajanen, a beginner level code lab by Ladies Learning Code and try out the winning game from Sudbury's own Game Design Challenge! Bring a laptop to participate in the code lab and a competitive (all in great fun) attitude to play the game designed by our local students.

Please register for the event at https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/women-in-technology-tickets-22046396365

events.name: Google Cloud Platform NEXT: streaming conference & codelabs
events.description:
Join us on day 1 of the Google Cloud Platform: NEXT conference to watch the opening keynote live! Discover the latest advances from Google and learn how to take advantage of them in your apps.

We'll follow the keynote with your choice of codelabs to put some of the new products through their paces: everything from building a simple node.js app that runs on Google Cloud Shell and taps into Google Storage and Datastore, up to harnessing the power of containers with Kubernetes!

A light lunch will be provided, so please RSVP so we don't run out of goodies :)﻿

events.name: Hands-on Virtual Reality: Google Cardboard and Unity
events.description:
If you've ever watched Aladdin, you'll remember the lyrics "A whole new world... a new fantastic point of view". That's what Google Cardboard is like the first time you experience it. Tonight, you can learn how to build VR experiences with Cardboard for others!

Join us in the world of virtual reality as we run not one, but TWO hands-on codelabs with Google Cardboard.

At 6:00 PM, Dan Scott will walk you through the process of capturing 360° images and posting them to the web so that they can be viewed on the desktop, with mobile browsers, and in Google Cardboard.

At 7:00 PM, Steve Forbes will take the lead and show you how to take what you learned about Unity from our last event, and combine that with the Cardboard SDK for Unity to build an Android application that works in Cardboard.

Bring a laptop and an Android device if you have one. We'll have a few Cardboard-compatible viewers for you to try out your creations.

events.name: Google I/O Extended 2016!
events.description:
Join us at the TimeHero office for Google I/O Extended!

Yes, we're holding it one week after the main I/O event, but with a huge bonus: we'll be taking part in a live Hangout with Q&A for the new Firebase features that will be unveiled during the I/O keynote, with two of the keynote speakers holding court.

After the Hangout, we'll run a codelab focused on Progressive Web Apps--an approach for making your web applications fast and responsive in connectivity situations ranging from great to none... and along the way, we'll have fun, share stories about our favourite elements that were unveiled at I/O, and eat some yummy food.

It'll be great--so come out and join us!

events.name: Progressive Web Apps: towards offline-first web sites
events.description:
Mere hours after the Progressive Web Apps Summit 2016 begins, we will meet to explore how to apply Progressive Web App (PWA) principles to our own web sites.

A PWA "is useful to users from the very first visit in a browser tab, no install required. As the user progressively builds a relationship with the App over time, it becomes more and more powerful. It loads quickly, even on flaky networks, sends relevant push notifications, has an icon on the home screen and loads as a top-level, full screen experience." (source: Your First Progressive Web App)

If you've created a few web pages and have dabbled in some JavaScript, then we think you'll find this event accessible and eye-opening! We've planned the following for the evening:

6:30 - doors open
7:00 - watch PWA Summit 2016 keynote
7:45 - work through a PWA codelab together
8:30 - your choice: watch another talk from the summit, do one more codelab, discussions, or work on your own
9:00 - wind things down

Note: to complete the codelabs, at the very least you will need to bring:

• a laptop with the Chrome browser (preferably Chrome Beta or Canary) installed

It would save a lot of time if you also have a working Node + NPM environment. Having git installed would be useful as well.

events.name: A Tour of Go Programming Language
events.description:
UPDATE: The meeting will be held in the Science 2 building in room F441

Join us and the Laurentian Math and Computer Science Club on Thursday July 21st, at 6PM at Laurentian University (Science 2 building room F441) for a tour of the Go programming language lead by Mavrick Laakso. 

Bring a laptop to follow along and try out some Go scripts!

events.name: Hot web technology: Angular 2.0 and Polymer
events.description:
Angular 2.0 was released on September 14th - let's celebrate by getting hands-on with an introduction to it!

We'll also build on the GDG-X Hoverboard template to create our DevFest 2016 site, giving us another close look at Polymer in practice.

events.name: DevFest 2016
events.description:
Our day-long DevFest, featuring hands-on codelabs (bring a laptop!) for Progressive Web Apps, AMP (Accelerated Mobile Pages) and schema.org, Google Cloud, Firebase, and more is going to be led by some of the best local developers.

Attendance is free for speakers, and a modest $5 fee for a full day of learning--including lunch, refreshments, and door prizes.

Our event site at https://devfest.gdgsudbury.ca/ includes the full schedule and speaker descriptions. Things kick off at 10:00 AM and will run until roughly 4:30PM. We're looking forward to seeing you!

events.name: Building Virtual Reality: Unity and AFrame.io
events.description:
Two of our speakers from DevFest 2016 return to give us more insight and some hands-on experience with building virtual reality experiences:

• Zachary will walk through the process of taking a Unity environment and turning it into an Android app that works on Google Cardboard

• Patrick will get us to go hands-on with AFrame.io, a web framework for building VR experiences that run on desktop and mobile browsers and require just a few lines of HTML

Bring a laptop and a mobile phone if you have one; we'll bring some Cardboard, and let's create some VR!

Attendance is free and open to all; even if you're just curious about technology, come on out and join us.

events.name: GCP Next - Extended
events.description:
Join us to take a concentrated dose of the best from the Google Cloud Platform (GCP) Next conference, including a technical keynote, one of the best technical talks, and one (or more, for the ambitious!) codelabs.

There will be food! There will be code! There will be cloud!

Bring a laptop. During this event, you will have free access to the Google Cloud Platform so that you can take it for a test drive with the codelabs--and in most cases, you'll be able to complete your work using only a browser.
events.how_to_find_us: The Brenda Wallace Computer Lab is on the left-hand side of the Library as you walk in, just past the washrooms, down a long dark hall. Don't be scared!

events.name: Women Techmakers - Building a Business/Career in Tech
events.description:
Come out to Women Techmakers - Building a Business/Career in Tech to hear from some local women making waves in the tech industry. The event will consist of a keynote presentation by Melanie Morin, CEO of StaffStat, followed by a panel discussion about successes and overcoming issues in various tech fields.

Stick around after for an opportunity to network and connect with the speakers and other attendees.

events.name: I/O Extended 2017 Sudbury!
events.description:
Come join us in the TimeHero offices for Google I/O Extended 2017

Only three weeks after the main event but just in time for the Google Home launch in Canada! We will be covering some of the highlights from Mountain View and I/O Extended Waterloo.

After covering some high points we will go through a codelab to build our own apps for Google Assistant.

Bring your laptop, bring your own I/O stories, we'll bring the food!

events.name: Mobile Sites Certification Info Session
events.description: Join us for an info session on earning a mobile site certification. We will be viewing a video that explains all the details of the certification then discussing the next steps to actually doing the certification requirements.

events.name: DevFest 2017
events.description:
GDG DevFest 2017 is our annual all-day developer conference that offers speaker sessions and codelabs that cover designing and building progressive web apps (PWAs) and more!

Our web site is live at https://devfest2017.gdgsudbury.ca and includes a complete schedule and list of speakers. We still have room for a few more lightning talks (5-10 minutes, it's a great way to get your feet wet with public speaking!); you can submit a proposal!

If you are interested in sponsoring the event so that we can offer better/more food, or swag, in exchange for the visibility of your organization, see the sponsorship prospectus for more details.

events.name: Mobile Sites Study Jam - Part 1
events.description: Studying together is more fun! Join us during this first session as we go over the first half of the Mobile Sites Certification study guide.

events.name: Mobile Sites Study Jam - Part 2
events.description: Studying together is more fun! Join us as we finish up the Mobile Sites study guide in preparation to take the final exam.

events.name: Holiday Get Together with WebVR
events.description:
Come out to the holiday party and build a GDG Sudbury holiday scene in WebVR. We'll be making 3D elements in A-Frame and adding it all to a local community scene

Stick around and we'll head over to Let's Scrabbalatte Board Game Café for lattes, board games, and some more VR fun

events.name: WTM/IWD 2018 - Starting a Project (Design)
events.description:
• What we'll do
Join us alongside Canada Learning Code as we put on a workshop on design docs. We will be covering the elements, layout and helping you set up your own design doc. Stayed tuned as more details become available.

• What to bring
a laptop will come in handy
events.how_to_find_us: At the top of the stairs in the Classroom building (next to the library) in the corner on the left by the washrooms. If you get lost message Emily or David

events.name: WTM/IWD 2018 - Starting a project (Technical)
events.description:
• What we'll do
Join us alongside Canada Learning Code as we put on a workshop on starting a project. Some things we will be looking include deciding on software and/or programming languages and where do you start to code. More details to come!

• What to bring
a laptop will come in handy
events.how_to_find_us: At the top of the stairs in the Classroom building (next to the library) in the corner on the left by the washrooms. If you get lost message Emily or David

events.name: I/O Extended 2018 Sudbury
events.description:
Join us after Google IO for a recap of the new announcements and releases that Google will be sharing during the conference in May.

Highlights:
Flutter - Will Larche (Google New York) will video conference in for an introduction to Flutter!
IO - One of our own (David) was live at IO and will be sharing his experience
Swag - We have some cool things to give away
Coffee! - Salute coffee and refreshments will be available

events.name: Machine Learning Study Jam
events.description:
New to machine learning but don't know where to start? Join us for a Machine Learning Study Jam where we will run through the Machine Learning Crash Course (MLCC)!

This course is intended for those who wish to learn about ML from a practical, applied perspective that will enable you to use machine learning in your everyday projects and learn about the power of TensorFlow. This is a great opportunity for anyone with basic technical knowledge and limited Machine Learning knowledge willing to gain some practical experience in ML and TensorFlow.

** Bring your laptop! **

events.name: AIY Vision

venue.name: Cliff Fielding Research, Innovation & Engineering Building

events.description:
Join us as we go over the AIY vision kit.

We will be covering the kit contents and some demos.

events.name: DevFest 2018

venue.name: Cliff Fielding Research, Innovation & Engineering Building

events.description:
GDG DevFest 2018 is our annual all-day developer conference that offers speaker sessions across multiple product areas, codelabs and more!

Bring your own laptop! We will have a limited number of laptops to borrow for the day. These will be on a first come basis, if you need to borrow one contact one of the organizers for arrangements.

Some highlights to look forward to:
* Digital Wellness
* Haptics
* Flutter
* Linux
events.how_to_find_us: We will be on the second floor in the Fielding Innovation Space (CF201)

events.name: Holiday get-together 2018
events.description:
Look forward to a holiday get-together again this year.

Last year was fun making a holiday theme in AR and playing some board games with each other that we have decided to plan another one this year.

Reach out to the organizers if you have any ideas.
events.how_to_find_us: Best parking is on Durham or Elgin. We have Scrabbalatte booked for the evening  so come in and find a table!

events.name: Cloud Study Jam

venue.name: Cliff Fielding Research, Innovation & Engineering Building

events.description:
Want to get started on the Google Cloud, but don't know where to begin? Join us for our Cloud Study Jam!

Get official Google training, a $55+ value, free of charge. Together we'll work through several Google Cloud labs. You will get hands-on experience with the Cloud Console, Kubernetes, Security, IoT on Cloud, and Machine Learning.

Then after our live session, you will have free access to more labs you can finish at home. Complete all labs in the quest and earn a Google-hosted badge for your online profile, and additional 30 days access to the training platform to compete any labs you want

Bring a laptop and charger (PC, Mac or Chromebook)! The labs will run on all of the latest versions of the popular browsers. For the best experience, make sure your laptop has Firefox or Chrome installed. Don’t forget your charger.

group_profile.intro: Dan Scott is a systems librarian at Laurentian University. He has contributed to open source software since his previous life at the Toronto IBM Software Development Lab.
Computer Science, Education graduate. MSc Computational Science candidate
